column4: When it was day

column5: and said
column6: "We have strictly bound ourselves by an oath to taste no food till we have killed Paul.

column4: You therefore
column5: along with the council

column4: Now the son of Paul's sister heard of their ambush; so he went and entered the barracks and told Paul.

column5: "Take this young man to the tribune; for he has something to tell him."

column4: So he took him and brought him to the tribune and said
column5: "Paul the prisoner called me and asked me to bring this young man to you
column6: as he has something to say to you."

column4: The tribune took him by the hand
column5: and going aside asked him privately
column6: "What is it that you have to tell me?"

column4: And he said
column5: "The Jews have agreed to ask you to bring Paul down to the council tomorrow

column5: charging him
column6: "Tell no one that you have informed me of this."

column4: Then he called two of the centurions and said

column4: And he wrote a letter to this effect:

Claudius Lys'ias to his Excellency the governor Felix, greeting.
Apostelgeschichte,23,27,This man was seized by the Jews, and was about to be killed by them, when I came upon them with the soldiers and rescued him, having learned that he was a Roman citizen.
Apostelgeschichte,23,28,And desiring to know the charge on which they accused him, I brought him down to their council.
Apostelgeschichte,23,29,I found that he was accused about questions of their law, but charged with nothing deserving death or imprisonment.
Apostelgeschichte,23,30,And when it was disclosed to me that there would be a plot against the man, I sent him to you at once, ordering his accusers also to state before you what they have against him.

column4: And on the morrow they returned to the barracks

column5: "let the men of authority among you go down with me

column5: Festus laid Paul's case before the king

column5: the chief priests and the elders of the Jews gave information about him

column5: and had opportunity to make his defense concerning the charge laid against him.

column4: When therefore they came together here

column4: When the accusers stood up

column5: "I should like to hear the man myself." "Tomorrow

column4: So on the morrow Agrippa and Berni'ce came with great pomp
column5: and they entered the audience hall with the military tribunes and the prominent men of the city. Then by command of Festus Paul was brought in.

column4: And Festus said
column5: "King Agrippa and all who are present with us

column7: both at Jerusalem and here
column8: shouting that he ought not to live any longer.

column5: I decided to send him.

column4: But I have nothing definite to write to my lord about him. Therefore I have brought him before you
column5: and
column6: especially before you
column7: King Agrippa
column8: that
column10: I may have something to write.

column4: For it seems to me unreasonable
column5: in sending a prisoner

column4: Agrippa said to Paul
column5: "You have permission to speak for yourself." Then Paul stretched out his hand and made his defense:

column4:
I think myself fortunate that it is before you, King Agrippa, I am to make my defense today against all the accusations of the Jews,
Apostelgeschichte,26,3,because you are especially familiar with all customs and controversies of the Jews; therefore I beg you to listen to me patiently.
Apostelgeschichte,26,4,My manner of life from my youth
column5: spent from the beginning among my own nation and at Jerusalem
column6: is known by all the Jews.

column4: They have known for a long time
column5: if they are willing to testify
column6: that according to the strictest party of our religion I have lived as a Pharisee.

column4: And now I stand here on trial for hope in the promise made by God to our fathers
to which our twelve tribes hope to attain
column5: as they earnestly worship night and day. And for this hope I am accused by Jews
column6: O king!

column4: Why is it thought incredible by any of you that God raises the dead?

I myself was convinced that I ought to do many things in opposing the name of Jesus of Nazareth.
Apostelgeschichte,26,10,And I did so in Jerusalem; I not only shut up many of the saints in prison, by authority from the chief priests, but when they were put to death I cast my vote against them.
Apostelgeschichte,26,11,And I punished them often in all the synagogues and tried to make them blaspheme; and in raging fury against them, I persecuted them even to foreign cities.
Apostelgeschichte,26,12,Thus I journeyed to Damascus with the authority and commission of the chief priests.
At midday
column5: O king
column6: I saw on the way a light from heaven
column7: brighter than the sun
column8: shining round me and those who journeyed with me.

column4: And when we had all fallen to the ground
column5: I heard a voice saying to me in the Hebrew language
column6: `Saul
column7: Saul
column8: why do you persecute me? It hurts you to kick against the goads.'

column4: And I said
column5: `Who are you
column6: Lord?' And the Lord said
column7: `I am Jesus whom you are persecuting.

column4: But rise and stand upon your feet; for I have appeared to you for this purpose
column5: to appoint you to serve and bear witness to the things in which you have seen me and to those in which I will appear to you

column4: delivering you from the people and from the Gentiles--to whom I send you
to open their eyes
column5: that they may turn from darkness to light and from the power of Satan to God
column6: that they may receive forgiveness of sins and a place among those who are sanctified by faith in me.'

column4:
Wherefore, O King Agrippa, I was not disobedient to the heavenly vision,
Apostelgeschichte,26,20,but declared first to those at Damascus, then at Jerusalem and throughout all the country of Judea, and also to the Gentiles, that they should repent and turn to God and perform deeds worthy of their repentance.
Apostelgeschichte,26,21,For this reason the Jews seized me in the temple and tried to kill me.
Apostelgeschichte,26,22,To this day I have had the help that comes from God, and so I stand here testifying both to small and great, saying nothing but what the prophets and Moses said would come to pass:
Apostelgeschichte,26,23,that the Christ must suffer, and that, by being the first to rise from the dead, he would proclaim light both to the people and to the Gentiles.
And as he thus made his defense
column5: Festus said with a loud voice
column6: "Paul
column7: you are mad; your great learning is turning you mad."

column4: But Paul said
column5: "I am not mad
column6: most excellent Festus
column7: but I am speaking the sober truth.

column4: For the king knows about these things
column5: and to him I speak freely; for I am persuaded that none of these things has escaped his notice
column6: for this was not done in a corner.

column4: King Agrippa
column5: do you believe the prophets? I know that you believe."

column4: And Agrippa said to Paul
column5: "In a short time you think to make me a Christian!"

column4: And Paul said
column5: "Whether short or long
column6: I would to God that not only you but also all who hear me this day might become such as I am--except for these chains."

column4: Then the king rose
column5: and the governor and Berni'ce and those who were sitting with them;

column5: they said to one another
column6: "This man is doing nothing to deserve death or imprisonment."

column4: And Agrippa said to Festus

column4: And when it was decided that we should sail for Italy
column5: they delivered Paul and some other prisoners to a centurion of the Augustan Cohort
column6: named Julius.

column4: And embarking in a ship of Adramyt'tium
column5: which was about to sail to the ports along the coast of Asia
column6: we put to sea
column7: accompanied by Aristar'chus
column8: a Macedo'nian from Thessaloni'ca.

column4: The next day we put in at Sidon; and Julius treated Paul kindly
column5: and gave him leave to go to his friends and be cared for.

column4: And putting to sea from there we sailed under the lee of Cyprus
column5: because the winds were against us.

column4: And when we had sailed across the sea which is off Cili'cia and Pamphyl'ia
column5: we came to Myra in Ly'cia.

column4: There the centurion found a ship of Alexandria sailing for Italy
column5: and put us on board.

column4: We sailed slowly for a number of days
column5: and arrived with difficulty off Cni'dus
column6: and as the wind did not allow us to go on
column7: we sailed under the lee of Crete off Salmo'ne.

column4: Coasting along it with difficulty
column5: we came to a place called Fair Havens
column6: near which was the city of Lase'a.

column4: As much time had been lost
column5: and the voyage was already dangerous because the fast had already gone by
column6: Paul advised them

column4: saying
column5: "Sirs
column6: I perceive that the voyage will be with injury and much loss
column7: not only of the cargo and the ship
column8: but also of our lives."

column4: But the centurion paid more attention to the captain and to the owner of the ship than to what Paul said.
And because the harbor was not suitable to winter in
column5: the majority advised to put to sea from there
column6: on the chance that somehow they could reach Phoenix
column7: a harbor of Crete
column8: looking northeast and southeast

column4: And when the south wind blew gently
column5: supposing that they had obtained their purpose
column6: they weighed anchor and sailed along Crete
column7: close inshore.

column4: But soon a tempestuous wind
column5: called the northeaster
column6: struck down from the land;

column4: and when the ship was caught and could not face the wind
column5: we gave way to it and were driven.

column4: And running under the lee of a small island called Cauda
column5: we managed with difficulty to secure the boat;

column4: after hoisting it up
column5: they took measures to undergird the ship; then
column6: fearing that they should run on the Syr'tis
column7: they lowered the gear
column8: and so were driven.

column4: As we were violently storm-tossed
column5: they began next day to throw the cargo overboard;

column4: and the third day they cast out with their own hands the tackle of the ship.
And when neither sun nor stars appeared for many a day
column5: and no small tempest lay on us
column6: all hope of our being saved was at last abandoned.

column4: As they had been long without food
column5: Paul then came forward among them and said
column6: "Men
column7: you should have listened to me
column8: and should not have set sail from Crete and incurred this injury and loss.

column4: I now bid you take heart; for there will be no loss of life among you
column5: but only of the ship.

column4: For this very night there stood by me an angel of the God to whom I belong and whom I worship
and he said
column5: `Do not be afraid
column6: Paul; you must stand before Caesar; and lo
column7: God has granted you all those who sail with you.'

column4: So take heart
column5: men
column6: for I have faith in God that it will be exactly as I have been told.

When the fourteenth night had come
column5: as we were drifting across the sea of A'dria
column6: about midnight the sailors suspected that they were nearing land.

column4: So they sounded and found twenty fathoms; a little farther on they sounded again and found fifteen fathoms.
And fearing that we might run on the rocks
column5: they let out four anchors from the stern
column6: and prayed for day to come.

column4: And as the sailors were seeking to escape from the ship
column5: and had lowered the boat into the sea
column6: under pretense of laying out anchors from the bow

column4: Paul said to the centurion and the soldiers
column5: "Unless these men stay in the ship
column6: you cannot be saved."

column4: Then the soldiers cut away the ropes of the boat
column5: and let it go.

column4: As day was about to dawn
column5: Paul urged them all to take some food
column6: saying
column7: "Today is the fourteenth day that you have continued in suspense and without food
column8: having taken nothing.

column4: Therefore I urge you to take some food; it will give you strength
column5: since not a hair is to perish from the head of any of you."

column4: And when he had said this
column5: he took bread
column6: and giving thanks to God in the presence of all he broke it and began to eat.

column4: Then they all were encouraged and ate some food themselves.

And when they had eaten enough
column5: they lightened the ship
column6: throwing out the wheat into the sea.

column4: Now when it was day
column5: they did not recognize the land
column6: but they noticed a bay with a beach
column7: on which they planned if possible to bring the ship ashore.

column4: So they cast off the anchors and left them in the sea
column5: at the same time loosening the ropes that tied the rudders; then hoisting the foresail to the wind they made for the beach.

column4: The soldiers' plan was to kill the prisoners
column5: lest any should swim away and escape;

column4: but the centurion
column5: wishing to save Paul
column6: kept them from carrying out their purpose. He ordered those who could swim to throw themselves overboard first and make for the land

column4: and the rest on planks or on pieces of the ship. And so it was that all escaped to land.
After we had escaped
column5: we then learned that the island was called Malta.

column4: And the natives showed us unusual kindness
column5: for they kindled a fire and welcomed us all
column6: because it had begun to rain and was cold.

column4: Paul had gathered a bundle of sticks and put them on the fire
column5: when a viper came out because of the heat and fastened on his hand.

column4: When the natives saw the creature hanging from his hand
column5: they said to one another
column6: "No doubt this man is a murderer. Though he has escaped from the sea
column7: justice has not allowed him to live."

column4: He
column5: however
column6: shook off the creature into the fire and suffered no harm.

column4: They waited
column5: expecting him to swell up or suddenly fall down dead; but when they had waited a long time and saw no misfortune come to him
column6: they changed their minds and said that he was a god.

column4: Now in the neighborhood of that place were lands belonging to the chief man of the island
column5: named Publius
column6: who received us and entertained us hospitably for three days.

column4: It happened that the father of Publius lay sick with fever and dysentery; and Paul visited him and prayed
column5: and putting his hands on him healed him.

column4: And when this had taken place
column5: the rest of the people on the island who had diseases also came and were cured.

column5: they put on board whatever we needed.

column4: After three months we set sail in a ship which had wintered in the island
column5: a ship of Alexandria
column6: with the Twin Brothers as figurehead.

column4: Putting in at Syracuse
column5: we stayed there for three days.

column4: And from there we made a circuit and arrived at Rhe'gium; and after one day a south wind sprang up
column5: and on the second day we came to Pute'oli.

column5: when they heard of us

column4: And when we came into Rome

column4: After three days he called together the local leaders of the Jews; and when they had gathered
column5: he said to them
column6: "Brethren
column7: though I had done nothing against the people or the customs of our fathers
column8: yet I was delivered prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans.

column5: they wished to set me at liberty
column6: because there was no reason for the death penalty in my case.

column4: But when the Jews objected
column5: I was compelled to appeal to Caesar--though I had no charge to bring against my nation.

column4: For this reason therefore I have asked to see you and speak with you
column5: since it is because of the hope of Israel that I am bound with this chain."

column4: And they said to him
column5: "We have received no letters from Judea about you

column4: But we desire to hear from you what your views are; for with regard to this sect we know that everywhere it is spoken against."
When they had appointed a day for him

column6: testifying to the kingdom of God and trying to convince them about Jesus both from the law of Moses and from the prophets.

column5: while others disbelieved.

column4: So
column5: as they disagreed among themselves

column7: after Paul had made one statement: "The Holy Spirit was right in saying to your fathers through Isaiah the prophet:

column4: `Go to this people
column5: and say
column6: You shall indeed hear but never understand

column5: and their ears are heavy of hearing
column6: and their eyes they have closed; lest they should perceive with their eyes
column7: and hear with their ears
column8: and understand with their heart
column9: and turn for me to heal them.'

And he lived there two whole years at his own expense
column5: and welcomed all who came to him

column4: preaching the kingdom of God and teaching about the Lord Jesus Christ quite openly and unhindered.
Paul
column5: a servant of Jesus Christ
column6: called to be an apostle
column7: set apart for the gospel of God

column4: which he promised beforehand through his prophets in the holy scriptures
the gospel concerning his Son
column5: who was descended from David according to the flesh

column4: and designated Son of God in power according to the Spirit of holiness by his resurrection from the dead
column5: Jesus Christ our Lord

column4: through whom we have received grace and apostleship to bring about the obedience of faith for the sake of his name among all the nations
including yourselves who are called to belong to Jesus Christ;
To all God's beloved in Rome
column5: who are called to be saints:  Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.

column4: First
column5: I thank my God through Jesus Christ for all of you
column6: because your faith is proclaimed in all the world.

column4: For God is my witness
column5: whom I serve with my spirit in the gospel of his Son
column6: that without ceasing I mention you always in my prayers

column4: asking that somehow by God's will I may now at last succeed in coming to you.
For I long to see you
column5: that I may impart to you some spiritual gift to strengthen you

column4: that is
column5: that we may be mutually encouraged by each other's faith
column6: both yours and mine.

column4: I want you to know
column5: brethren
column6: that I have often intended to come to you (but thus far have been prevented)
column7: in order that I may reap some harvest among you as well as among the rest of the Gentiles.

column4: I am under obligation both to Greeks and to barbarians
column5: both to the wise and to the foolish:

column4: so I am eager to preach the gospel to you also who are in Rome.
For I am not ashamed of the gospel: it is the power of God for salvation to every one who has faith
column5: to the Jew first and also to the Greek.

column4: For in it the righteousness of God is revealed through faith for faith; as it is written
column5: "He who through faith is righteous shall live."

column4: For the wrath of God is revealed from heaven against all ungodliness and wickedness of men who by their wickedness suppress the truth.
For what can be known about God is plain to them
column5: because God has shown it to them.

column4: Ever since the creation of the world his invisible nature
column5: namely
column6: his eternal power and deity
column7: has been clearly perceived in the things that have been made. So they are without excuse;

column4: for although they knew God they did not honor him as God or give thanks to him
column5: but they became futile in their thinking and their senseless minds were darkened.

column4: Claiming to be wise
column5: they became fools

column4: and exchanged the glory of the immortal God for images resembling mortal man or birds or animals or reptiles.
Therefore God gave them up in the lusts of their hearts to impurity

Römer,5,1,Therefore, since we are justified by faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ.
Römer,5,2,Through him we have obtained access to this grace in which we stand, and we rejoice in our hope of sharing the glory of God.

Römer,5,4,and endurance produces character, and character produces hope,

Römer,5,6,While we were still weak, at the right time Christ died for the ungodly.
Römer,5,7,Why, one will hardly die for a righteous man--though perhaps for a good man one will dare even to die.
Römer,5,8,But God shows his love for us in that while we were yet sinners Christ died for us.
Römer,5,9,Since, therefore, we are now justified by his blood, much more shall we be saved by him from the wrath of God.
Römer,5,10,For if while we were enemies we were reconciled to God by the death of his Son, much more, now that we are reconciled, shall we be saved by his life.
Römer,5,11,Not only so, but we also rejoice in God through our Lord Jesus Christ, through whom we have now received our reconciliation.
Römer,5,12,Therefore as sin came into the world through one man and death through sin, and so death spread to all men because all men sinned--
Römer,5,13,sin indeed was in the world before the law was given, but sin is not counted where there is no law.
Römer,5,14,Yet death reigned from Adam to Moses, even over those whose sins were not like the transgression of Adam, who was a type of the one who was to come.
Römer,5,15,But the free gift is not like the trespass. For if many died through one man's trespass, much more have the grace of God and the free gift in the grace of that one man Jesus Christ abounded for many.
Römer,5,16,And the free gift is not like the effect of that one man's sin. For the judgment following one trespass brought condemnation, but the free gift following many trespasses brings justification.
Römer,5,17,If, because of one man's trespass, death reigned through that one man, much more will those who receive the abundance of grace and the free gift of righteousness reign in life through the one man Jesus Christ.
Römer,5,18,Then as one man's trespass led to condemnation for all men, so one man's act of righteousness leads to acquittal and life for all men.
Römer,5,19,For as by one man's disobedience many were made sinners, so by one man's obedience many will be made righteous.
Römer,5,20,Law came in, to increase the trespass; but where sin increased, grace abounded all the more,
Römer,5,21,so that, as sin reigned in death, grace also might reign through righteousness to eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord.
Römer,6,1,What shall we say then? Are we to continue in sin that grace may abound?
Römer,6,2,By no means! How can we who died to sin still live in it?
Römer,6,3,Do you not know that all of us who have been baptized into Christ Jesus were baptized into his death?
Römer,6,4,We were buried therefore with him by baptism into death, so that as Christ was raised from the dead by the glory of the Father, we too might walk in newness of life.
Römer,6,5,For if we have been united with him in a death like his, we shall certainly be united with him in a resurrection like his.
Römer,6,6,We know that our old self was crucified with him so that the sinful body might be destroyed, and we might no longer be enslaved to sin.
Römer,6,7,For he who has died is freed from sin.
Römer,6,8,But if we have died with Christ, we believe that we shall also live with him.
Römer,6,9,For we know that Christ being raised from the dead will never die again; death no longer has dominion over him.
Römer,6,10,The death he died he died to sin, once for all, but the life he lives he lives to God.
Römer,6,11,So you also must consider yourselves dead to sin and alive to God in Christ Jesus.
Römer,6,12,Let not sin therefore reign in your mortal bodies, to make you obey their passions.
Römer,6,13,Do not yield your members to sin as instruments of wickedness, but yield yourselves to God as men who have been brought from death to life, and your members to God as instruments of righteousness.
Römer,6,14,For sin will have no dominion over you, since you are not under law but under grace.
Römer,6,15,What then? Are we to sin because we are not under law but under grace? By no means!
Römer,6,16,Do you not know that if you yield yourselves to any one as obedient slaves, you are slaves of the one whom you obey, either of sin, which leads to death, or of obedience, which leads to righteousness?
Römer,6,17,But thanks be to God, that you who were once slaves of sin have become obedient from the heart to the standard of teaching to which you were committed,
Römer,6,18,and, having been set free from sin, have become slaves of righteousness.
Römer,6,19,I am speaking in human terms, because of your natural limitations. For just as you once yielded your members to impurity and to greater and greater iniquity, so now yield your members to righteousness for sanctification.
Römer,6,20,When you were slaves of sin, you were free in regard to righteousness.
Römer,6,21,But then what return did you get from the things of which you are now ashamed? The end of those things is death.
Römer,6,22,But now that you have been set free from sin and have become slaves of God, the return you get is sanctification and its end, eternal life.
Römer,6,23,For the wages of sin is death, but the free gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.

2 Korinther,4,9,persecuted, but not forsaken; struck down, but not destroyed;
2 Korinther,4,10,always carrying in the body the death of Jesus, so that the life of Jesus may also be manifested in our bodies.
2 Korinther,4,11,For while we live we are always being given up to death for Jesus' sake, so that the life of Jesus may be manifested in our mortal flesh.
2 Korinther,4,12,So death is at work in us, but life in you.
2 Korinther,4,13,Since we have the same spirit of faith as he had who wrote, I believed
column7: and so I spoke
column8:
we too believe, and so we speak,
2 Korinther,4,14,knowing that he who raised the Lord Jesus will raise us also with Jesus and bring us with you into his presence.
2 Korinther,4,15,For it is all for your sake, so that as grace extends to more and more people it may increase thanksgiving, to the glory of God.
2 Korinther,4,16,So we do not lose heart. Though our outer nature is wasting away, our inner nature is being renewed every day.
2 Korinther,4,17,For this slight momentary affliction is preparing for us an eternal weight of glory beyond all comparison,
2 Korinther,4,18,because we look not to the things that are seen but to the things that are unseen; for the things that are seen are transient, but the things that are unseen are eternal.
2 Korinther,5,1,For we know that if the earthly tent we live in is destroyed, we have a building from God, a house not made with hands, eternal in the heavens.
2 Korinther,5,2,Here indeed we groan, and long to put on our heavenly dwelling,
2 Korinther,5,3,so that by putting it on we may not be found naked.
2 Korinther,5,4,For while we are still in this tent, we sigh with anxiety; not that we would be unclothed, but that we would be further clothed, so that what is mortal may be swallowed up by life.
2 Korinther,5,5,He who has prepared us for this very thing is God, who has given us the Spirit as a guarantee.
2 Korinther,5,6,So we are always of good courage; we know that while we are at home in the body we are away from the Lord,
2 Korinther,5,7,for we walk by faith, not by sight.
2 Korinther,5,8,We are of good courage, and we would rather be away from the body and at home with the Lord.
2 Korinther,5,9,So whether we are at home or away, we make it our aim to please him.
2 Korinther,5,10,For we must all appear before the judgment seat of Christ, so that each one may receive good or evil, according to what he has done in the body.
2 Korinther,5,11,Therefore, knowing the fear of the Lord, we persuade men; but what we are is known to God, and I hope it is known also to your conscience.
2 Korinther,5,12,We are not commending ourselves to you again but giving you cause to be proud of us, so that you may be able to answer those who pride themselves on a man's position and not on his heart.
2 Korinther,5,13,For if we are beside ourselves, it is for God; if we are in our right mind, it is for you.
2 Korinther,5,14,For the love of Christ controls us, because we are convinced that one has died for all; therefore all have died.
2 Korinther,5,15,And he died for all, that those who live might live no longer for themselves but for him who for their sake died and was raised.
2 Korinther,5,16,From now on, therefore, we regard no one from a human point of view; even though we once regarded Christ from a human point of view, we regard him thus no longer.
2 Korinther,5,17,Therefore, if any one is in Christ, he is a new creation; the old has passed away, behold, the new has come.
2 Korinther,5,18,All this is from God, who through Christ reconciled us to himself and gave us the ministry of reconciliation;
2 Korinther,5,19,that is, in Christ God was reconciling the world to himself, not counting their trespasses against them, and entrusting to us the message of reconciliation.
2 Korinther,5,20,So we are ambassadors for Christ, God making his appeal through us. We beseech you on behalf of Christ, be reconciled to God.
2 Korinther,5,21,For our sake he made him to be sin who knew no sin, so that in him we might become the righteousness of God.
2 Korinther,6,1,Working together with him, then, we entreat you not to accept the grace of God in vain.

Galater,3,17,This is what I mean: the law, which came four hundred and thirty years afterward, does not annul a covenant previously ratified by God, so as to make the promise void.
Galater,3,18,For if the inheritance is by the law, it is no longer by promise; but God gave it to Abraham by a promise.

1 Thessalonicher,5,4,But you are not in darkness, brethren, for that day to surprise you like a thief.
1 Thessalonicher,5,5,For you are all sons of light and sons of the day; we are not of the night or of darkness.
1 Thessalonicher,5,6,So then let us not sleep, as others do, but let us keep awake and be sober.
1 Thessalonicher,5,7,For those who sleep sleep at night, and those who get drunk are drunk at night.
1 Thessalonicher,5,8,But, since we belong to the day, let us be sober, and put on the breastplate of faith and love, and for a helmet the hope of salvation.
1 Thessalonicher,5,9,For God has not destined us for wrath, but to obtain salvation through our Lord Jesus Christ,
1 Thessalonicher,5,10,who died for us so that whether we wake or sleep we might live with him.
1 Thessalonicher,5,11,Therefore encourage one another and build one another up, just as you are doing.
1 Thessalonicher,5,12,But we beseech you, brethren, to respect those who labor among you and are over you in the Lord and admonish you,
1 Thessalonicher,5,13,and to esteem them very highly in love because of their work. Be at peace among yourselves.
1 Thessalonicher,5,14,And we exhort you, brethren, admonish the idlers, encourage the fainthearted, help the weak, be patient with them all.
1 Thessalonicher,5,15,See that none of you repays evil for evil, but always seek to do good to one another and to all.
1 Thessalonicher,5,16,Rejoice always,
1 Thessalonicher,5,17,pray constantly,
1 Thessalonicher,5,18,give thanks in all circumstances; for this is the will of God in Christ Jesus for you.
1 Thessalonicher,5,19,Do not quench the Spirit,
1 Thessalonicher,5,20,do not despise prophesying,
1 Thessalonicher,5,21,but test everything; hold fast what is good,
1 Thessalonicher,5,22,abstain from every form of evil.
1 Thessalonicher,5,23,May the God of peace himself sanctify you wholly; and may your spirit and soul and body be kept sound and blameless at the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ.
1 Thessalonicher,5,24,He who calls you is faithful, and he will do it.
1 Thessalonicher,5,25,Brethren, pray for us.
1 Thessalonicher,5,26,Greet all the brethren with a holy kiss.
1 Thessalonicher,5,27,I adjure you by the Lord that this letter be read to all the brethren.
1 Thessalonicher,5,28,The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you.
2 Thessalonicher,1,1,Paul, Silva'nus, and Timothy, To the church of the Thessalo'nians in God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ:
2 Thessalonicher,1,2,Grace to you and peace from God the Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
2 Thessalonicher,1,3,We are bound to give thanks to God always for you, brethren, as is fitting, because your faith is growing abundantly, and the love of every one of you for one another is increasing.
2 Thessalonicher,1,4,Therefore we ourselves boast of you in the churches of God for your steadfastness and faith in all your persecutions and in the afflictions which you are enduring.
2 Thessalonicher,1,5,This is evidence of the righteous judgment of God, that you may be made worthy of the kingdom of God, for which you are suffering--
2 Thessalonicher,1,6,since indeed God deems it just to repay with affliction those who afflict you,
2 Thessalonicher,1,7,and to grant rest with us to you who are afflicted, when the Lord Jesus is revealed from heaven with his mighty angels in flaming fire,
2 Thessalonicher,1,8,inflicting vengeance upon those who do not know God and upon those who do not obey the gospel of our Lord Jesus.
2 Thessalonicher,1,9,They shall suffer the punishment of eternal destruction and exclusion from the presence of the Lord and from the glory of his might,
2 Thessalonicher,1,10,when he comes on that day to be glorified in his saints, and to be marveled at in all who have believed, because our testimony to you was believed.
2 Thessalonicher,1,11,To this end we always pray for you, that our God may make you worthy of his call, and may fulfil every good resolve and work of faith by his power,
2 Thessalonicher,1,12,so that the name of our Lord Jesus may be glorified in you, and you in him, according to the grace of our God and the Lord Jesus Christ.
2 Thessalonicher,2,1,Now concerning the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ and our assembling to meet him, we beg you, brethren,
2 Thessalonicher,2,2,not to be quickly shaken in mind or excited, either by spirit or by word, or by letter purporting to be from us, to the effect that the day of the Lord has come.
2 Thessalonicher,2,3,Let no one deceive you in any way; for that day will not come, unless the rebellion comes first, and the man of lawlessness is revealed, the son of perdition,
2 Thessalonicher,2,4,who opposes and exalts himself against every so-called god or object of worship, so that he takes his seat in the temple of God, proclaiming himself to be God.
2 Thessalonicher,2,5,Do you not remember that when I was still with you I told you this?
2 Thessalonicher,2,6,And you know what is restraining him now so that he may be revealed in his time.
2 Thessalonicher,2,7,For the mystery of lawlessness is already at work; only he who now restrains it will do so until he is out of the way.
2 Thessalonicher,2,8,And then the lawless one will be revealed, and the Lord Jesus will slay him with the breath of his mouth and destroy him by his appearing and his coming.
2 Thessalonicher,2,9,The coming of the lawless one by the activity of Satan will be with all power and with pretended signs and wonders,
2 Thessalonicher,2,10,and with all wicked deception for those who are to perish, because they refused to love the truth and so be saved.
2 Thessalonicher,2,11,Therefore God sends upon them a strong delusion, to make them believe what is false,
2 Thessalonicher,2,12,so that all may be condemned who did not believe the truth but had pleasure in unrighteousness.
2 Thessalonicher,2,13,But we are bound to give thanks to God always for you, brethren beloved by the Lord, because God chose you from the beginning to be saved, through sanctification by the Spirit and belief in the truth.
2 Thessalonicher,2,14,To this he called you through our gospel, so that you may obtain the glory of our Lord Jesus Christ.
2 Thessalonicher,2,15,So then, brethren, stand firm and hold to the traditions which you were taught by us, either by word of mouth or by letter.
2 Thessalonicher,2,16,Now may our Lord Jesus Christ himself, and God our Father, who loved us and gave us eternal comfort and good hope through grace,
2 Thessalonicher,2,17,comfort your hearts and establish them in every good work and word.
2 Thessalonicher,3,1,Finally, brethren, pray for us, that the word of the Lord may speed on and triumph, as it did among you,
2 Thessalonicher,3,2,and that we may be delivered from wicked and evil men; for not all have faith.
2 Thessalonicher,3,3,But the Lord is faithful; he will strengthen you and guard you from evil.
2 Thessalonicher,3,4,And we have confidence in the Lord about you, that you are doing and will do the things which we command.
2 Thessalonicher,3,5,May the Lord direct your hearts to the love of God and to the steadfastness of Christ.
2 Thessalonicher,3,6,Now we command you, brethren, in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that you keep away from any brother who is living in idleness and not in accord with the tradition that you received from us.
2 Thessalonicher,3,7,For you yourselves know how you ought to imitate us; we were not idle when we were with you,
2 Thessalonicher,3,8,we did not eat any one's bread without paying, but with toil and labor we worked night and day, that we might not burden any of you.
2 Thessalonicher,3,9,It was not because we have not that right, but to give you in our conduct an example to imitate.
2 Thessalonicher,3,10,For even when we were with you, we gave you this command: If any one will not work, let him not eat.
2 Thessalonicher,3,11,For we hear that some of you are living in idleness, mere busybodies, not doing any work.
2 Thessalonicher,3,12,Now such persons we command and exhort in the Lord Jesus Christ to do their work in quietness and to earn their own living.
2 Thessalonicher,3,13,Brethren, do not be weary in well-doing.
2 Thessalonicher,3,14,If any one refuses to obey what we say in this letter, note that man, and have nothing to do with him, that he may be ashamed.
2 Thessalonicher,3,15,Do not look on him as an enemy, but warn him as a brother.
2 Thessalonicher,3,16,Now may the Lord of peace himself give you peace at all times in all ways. The Lord be with you all.
2 Thessalonicher,3,17,I, Paul, write this greeting with my own hand. This is the mark in every letter of mine; it is the way I write.
2 Thessalonicher,3,18,The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all.
1 Timotheus,1,1,Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus by command of God our Savior and of Christ Jesus our hope,
1 Timotheus,1,2,To Timothy, my true child in the faith:  Grace, mercy, and peace from God the Father and Christ Jesus our Lord.
1 Timotheus,1,3,As I urged you when I was going to Macedonia, remain at Ephesus that you may charge certain persons not to teach any different doctrine,
1 Timotheus,1,4,nor to occupy themselves with myths and endless genealogies which promote speculations rather than the divine training that is in faith;
1 Timotheus,1,5,whereas the aim of our charge is love that issues from a pure heart and a good conscience and sincere faith.
1 Timotheus,1,6,Certain persons by swerving from these have wandered away into vain discussion,
1 Timotheus,1,7,desiring to be teachers of the law, without understanding either what they are saying or the things about which they make assertions.
1 Timotheus,1,8,Now we know that the law is good, if any one uses it lawfully,
1 Timotheus,1,9,understanding this, that the law is not laid down for the just but for the lawless and disobedient, for the ungodly and sinners, for the unholy and profane, for murderers of fathers and murderers of mothers, for manslayers,
1 Timotheus,1,10,immoral persons, sodomites, kidnapers, liars, perjurers, and whatever else is contrary to sound doctrine,
1 Timotheus,1,11,in accordance with the glorious gospel of the blessed God with which I have been entrusted.
1 Timotheus,1,12,I thank him who has given me strength for this, Christ Jesus our Lord, because he judged me faithful by appointing me to his service,
1 Timotheus,1,13,though I formerly blasphemed and persecuted and insulted him; but I received mercy because I had acted ignorantly in unbelief,
1 Timotheus,1,14,and the grace of our Lord overflowed for me with the faith and love that are in Christ Jesus.
1 Timotheus,1,15,The saying is sure and worthy of full acceptance, that Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners. And I am the foremost of sinners;
1 Timotheus,1,16,but I received mercy for this reason, that in me, as the foremost, Jesus Christ might display his perfect patience for an example to those who were to believe in him for eternal life.
1 Timotheus,1,17,To the King of ages, immortal, invisible, the only God, be honor and glory for ever and ever. Amen.
1 Timotheus,1,18,This charge I commit to you, Timothy, my son, in accordance with the prophetic utterances which pointed to you, that inspired by them you may wage the good warfare,
1 Timotheus,1,19,holding faith and a good conscience. By rejecting conscience, certain persons have made shipwreck of their faith,
1 Timotheus,1,20,among them Hymenae'us and Alexander, whom I have delivered to Satan that they may learn not to blaspheme.
1 Timotheus,2,1,First of all, then, I urge that supplications, prayers, intercessions, and thanksgivings be made for all men,
1 Timotheus,2,2,for kings and all who are in high positions, that we may lead a quiet and peaceable life, godly and respectful in every way.
1 Timotheus,2,3,This is good, and it is acceptable in the sight of God our Savior,
1 Timotheus,2,4,who desires all men to be saved and to come to the knowledge of the truth.
1 Timotheus,2,5,For there is one God, and there is one mediator between God and men, the man Christ Jesus,
1 Timotheus,2,6,who gave himself as a ransom for all, the testimony to which was borne at the proper time.
1 Timotheus,2,7,For this I was appointed a preacher and apostle (I am telling the truth, I am not lying), a teacher of the Gentiles in faith and truth.
1 Timotheus,2,8,I desire then that in every place the men should pray, lifting holy hands without anger or quarreling;
1 Timotheus,2,9,also that women should adorn themselves modestly and sensibly in seemly apparel, not with braided hair or gold or pearls or costly attire
1 Timotheus,2,10,but by good deeds, as befits women who profess religion.
1 Timotheus,2,11,Let a woman learn in silence with all submissiveness.
1 Timotheus,2,12,I permit no woman to teach or to have authority over men; she is to keep silent.
1 Timotheus,2,13,For Adam was formed first, then Eve;
1 Timotheus,2,14,and Adam was not deceived, but the woman was deceived and became a transgressor.
1 Timotheus,2,15,Yet woman will be saved through bearing children, if she continues in faith and love and holiness, with modesty.
1 Timotheus,3,1,The saying is sure: If any one aspires to the office of bishop, he desires a noble task.
1 Timotheus,3,2,Now a bishop must be above reproach, the husband of one wife, temperate, sensible, dignified, hospitable, an apt teacher,
1 Timotheus,3,3,no drunkard, not violent but gentle, not quarrelsome, and no lover of money.
1 Timotheus,3,4,He must manage his own household well, keeping his children submissive and respectful in every way;
1 Timotheus,3,5,for if a man does not know how to manage his own household, how can he care for God's church?
1 Timotheus,3,6,He must not be a recent convert, or he may be puffed up with conceit and fall into the condemnation of the devil;
1 Timotheus,3,7,moreover he must be well thought of by outsiders, or he may fall into reproach and the snare of the devil.
1 Timotheus,3,8,Deacons likewise must be serious, not double-tongued, not addicted to much wine, not greedy for gain;
1 Timotheus,3,9,they must hold the mystery of the faith with a clear conscience.
1 Timotheus,3,10,And let them also be tested first; then if they prove themselves blameless let them serve as deacons.
1 Timotheus,3,11,The women likewise must be serious, no slanderers, but temperate, faithful in all things.
1 Timotheus,3,12,Let deacons be the husband of one wife, and let them manage their children and their households well;
1 Timotheus,3,13,for those who serve well as deacons gain a good standing for themselves and also great confidence in the faith which is in Christ Jesus.
1 Timotheus,3,14,I hope to come to you soon, but I am writing these instructions to you so that,
1 Timotheus,3,15,if I am delayed, you may know how one ought to behave in the household of God, which is the church of the living God, the pillar and bulwark of the truth.
1 Timotheus,3,16,Great indeed, we confess, is the mystery of our religion:  He was manifested in the flesh, vindicated in the Spirit, seen by angels, preached among the nations, believed on in the world, taken up in glory.
1 Timotheus,4,1,Now the Spirit expressly says that in later times some will depart from the faith by giving heed to deceitful spirits and doctrines of demons,
1 Timotheus,4,2,through the pretensions of liars whose consciences are seared,
1 Timotheus,4,3,who forbid marriage and enjoin abstinence from foods which God created to be received with thanksgiving by those who believe and know the truth.
1 Timotheus,4,4,For everything created by God is good, and nothing is to be rejected if it is received with thanksgiving;
1 Timotheus,4,5,for then it is consecrated by the word of God and prayer.
1 Timotheus,4,6,If you put these instructions before the brethren, you will be a good minister of Christ Jesus, nourished on the words of the faith and of the good doctrine which you have followed.
1 Timotheus,4,7,Have nothing to do with godless and silly myths. Train yourself in godliness;
1 Timotheus,4,8,for while bodily training is of some value, godliness is of value in every way, as it holds promise for the present life and also for the life to come.
1 Timotheus,4,9,The saying is sure and worthy of full acceptance.
1 Timotheus,4,10,For to this end we toil and strive, because we have our hope set on the living God, who is the Savior of all men, especially of those who believe.
1 Timotheus,4,11,Command and teach these things.
1 Timotheus,4,12,Let no one despise your youth, but set the believers an example in speech and conduct, in love, in faith, in purity.
1 Timotheus,4,13,Till I come, attend to the public reading of scripture, to preaching, to teaching.
1 Timotheus,4,14,Do not neglect the gift you have, which was given you by prophetic utterance when the council of elders laid their hands upon you.
1 Timotheus,4,15,Practice these duties, devote yourself to them, so that all may see your progress.
1 Timotheus,4,16,Take heed to yourself and to your teaching; hold to that, for by so doing you will save both yourself and your hearers.
1 Timotheus,5,1,Do not rebuke an older man but exhort him as you would a father; treat younger men like brothers,
1 Timotheus,5,2,older women like mothers, younger women like sisters, in all purity.
1 Timotheus,5,3,Honor widows who are real widows.
1 Timotheus,5,4,If a widow has children or grandchildren, let them first learn their religious duty to their own family and make some return to their parents; for this is acceptable in the sight of God.
1 Timotheus,5,5,She who is a real widow, and is left all alone, has set her hope on God and continues in supplications and prayers night and day;
1 Timotheus,5,6,whereas she who is self-indulgent is dead even while she lives.
1 Timotheus,5,7,Command this, so that they may be without reproach.
1 Timotheus,5,8,If any one does not provide for his relatives, and especially for his own family, he has disowned the faith and is worse than an unbeliever.
1 Timotheus,5,9,Let a widow be enrolled if she is not less than sixty years of age, having been the wife of one husband;
1 Timotheus,5,10,and she must be well attested for her good deeds, as one who has brought up children, shown hospitality, washed the feet of the saints, relieved the afflicted, and devoted herself to doing good in every way.
1 Timotheus,5,11,But refuse to enrol younger widows; for when they grow wanton against Christ they desire to marry,
1 Timotheus,5,12,and so they incur condemnation for having violated their first pledge.
1 Timotheus,5,13,Besides that, they learn to be idlers, gadding about from house to house, and not only idlers but gossips and busybodies, saying what they should not.
1 Timotheus,5,14,So I would have younger widows marry, bear children, rule their households, and give the enemy no occasion to revile us.
1 Timotheus,5,15,For some have already strayed after Satan.
1 Timotheus,5,16,If any believing woman has relatives who are widows, let her assist them; let the church not be burdened, so that it may assist those who are real widows.
1 Timotheus,5,17,Let the elders who rule well be considered worthy of double honor, especially those who labor in preaching and teaching;
1 Timotheus,5,18,for the scripture says, You shall not muzzle an ox when it is treading out the grain
column7: and, The laborer deserves his wages."

column4: Never admit any charge against an elder except on the evidence of two or three witnesses.
As for those who persist in sin
column5: rebuke them in the presence of all
column6: so that the rest may stand in fear.

column4: In the presence of God and of Christ Jesus and of the elect angels I charge you to keep these rules without favor
column5: doing nothing from partiality.

column4: Do not be hasty in the laying on of hands
column5: nor participate in another man's sins; keep yourself pure.

column4: No longer drink only water
column5: but use a little wine for the sake of your stomach and your frequent ailments.

column4: The sins of some men are conspicuous
column5: pointing to judgment
column6: but the sins of others appear later.

column4: So also good deeds are conspicuous; and even when they are not
column5: they cannot remain hidden.

column4: Let all who are under the yoke of slavery regard their masters as worthy of all honor

2 Petrus,1,18,we heard this voice borne from heaven, for we were with him on the holy mountain.
2 Petrus,1,19,And we have the prophetic word made more sure. You will do well to pay attention to this as to a lamp shining in a dark place, until the day dawns and the morning star rises in your hearts.
2 Petrus,1,20,First of all you must understand this, that no prophecy of scripture is a matter of one's own interpretation,

2 Petrus,2,1,But false prophets also arose among the people, just as there will be false teachers among you, who will secretly bring in destructive heresies, even denying the Master who bought them, bringing upon themselves swift destruction.
2 Petrus,2,2,And many will follow their licentiousness, and because of them the way of truth will be reviled.
2 Petrus,2,3,And in their greed they will exploit you with false words; from of old their condemnation has not been idle, and their destruction has not been asleep.
2 Petrus,2,4,For if God did not spare the angels when they sinned, but cast them into hell and committed them to pits of nether gloom to be kept until the judgment;
2 Petrus,2,5,if he did not spare the ancient world, but preserved Noah, a herald of righteousness, with seven other persons, when he brought a flood upon the world of the ungodly;
2 Petrus,2,6,if by turning the cities of Sodom and Gomor'rah to ashes he condemned them to extinction and made them an example to those who were to be ungodly;
2 Petrus,2,7,and if he rescued righteous Lot, greatly distressed by the licentiousness of the wicked
2 Petrus,2,8,(for by what that righteous man saw and heard as he lived among them, he was vexed in his righteous soul day after day with their lawless deeds),
2 Petrus,2,9,then the Lord knows how to rescue the godly from trial, and to keep the unrighteous under punishment until the day of judgment,
2 Petrus,2,10,and especially those who indulge in the lust of defiling passion and despise authority.  Bold and wilful, they are not afraid to revile the glorious ones,
2 Petrus,2,11,whereas angels, though greater in might and power, do not pronounce a reviling judgment upon them before the Lord.
2 Petrus,2,12,But these, like irrational animals, creatures of instinct, born to be caught and killed, reviling in matters of which they are ignorant, will be destroyed in the same destruction with them,
2 Petrus,2,13,suffering wrong for their wrongdoing. They count it pleasure to revel in the daytime. They are blots and blemishes, reveling in their dissipation, carousing with you.
2 Petrus,2,14,They have eyes full of adultery, insatiable for sin. They entice unsteady souls. They have hearts trained in greed. Accursed children!
2 Petrus,2,15,Forsaking the right way they have gone astray; they have followed the way of Balaam, the son of Be'or, who loved gain from wrongdoing,
2 Petrus,2,16,but was rebuked for his own transgression; a dumb ass spoke with human voice and restrained the prophet's madness.
2 Petrus,2,17,These are waterless springs and mists driven by a storm; for them the nether gloom of darkness has been reserved.
2 Petrus,2,18,For, uttering loud boasts of folly, they entice with licentious passions of the flesh men who have barely escaped from those who live in error.
2 Petrus,2,19,They promise them freedom, but they themselves are slaves of corruption; for whatever overcomes a man, to that he is enslaved.
2 Petrus,2,20,For if, after they have escaped the defilements of the world through the knowledge of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ, they are again entangled in them and overpowered, the last state has become worse for them than the first.
2 Petrus,2,21,For it would have been better for them never to have known the way of righteousness than after knowing it to turn back from the holy commandment delivered to them.
2 Petrus,2,22,It has happened to them according to the true proverb, The dog turns back to his own vomit, and the sow is washed only to wallow in the mire.
